Whole Lotta Red

After over a year and a half of hype, Playboi Carti’s highly anticipated second album Whole Lotta Red was released last year on December 25th. Coming in with a whopping 24 songs, the album was either the best Christmas gift for some fans or a heaping pile of coal for others. The overall response towards the album was divided, you had those who appreciated this new, “punk” aesthetic and abrasive sound, and others who despised it, calling the album lazy and messy. I too didn’t know what to think of WLR for the past eight months. Part of me was iffy about the whole thing, yet I found myself going back and listening to the album every so often. It wasn’t until recently while watching Carti’s Lollapalooza performance that I decided to give WLR another listen, and oddly enough I finally have my own verdict. Whole Lotta Red is by no means an amazing album, nor is it a bad album either. At its best, Carti matches the psyched-out beats with his melodic and new hard-hitting punk side. At its worst, Whole Lotta Red is filled with so many throwaway tracks that could have been left on the cutting room floor, that sour the overall experience. What we get is an album that is equal parts good, and mediocre. The production for WLR was a surprise, primarily because of the lack of Pi’erre Bourne beats. The producer who helped hone in Carti’s sound on breakout tracks like “Magnolia”, “Wokeuplikethis” and “R.I.P.” Is almost nowhere to be found, save for only two songs “Place” and “ILoveUIHateU”. The majority of WLR’s production is handled by F1lthy, Art Dealer, Star Boy, and Maaly Raw among others. They provide Carti with some of the glitchiest, frenetic beats he’s ever rapped on. Songs like the blaring opener “Rockstar Made”, the chaotic bass of “Stop Breathing”, “Die4Guy” and “New Tank” or the ear-splitting “OnThatTime” all fit into this new punk trap aesthetic Carti’s going for on WLR. When Carti finds that balance between punk and trap is when WLR shines, and these aforementioned songs exemplify that. Unfortunately, it gets a little too much to handle, as oftentimes the production would leave me feeling confused. As is the case with the song “Control”, there are these weird EDM synths and drum beats that remind me too much of that weird stage in the 2010s when all music tried to be dubstep. “Vamp Anthem” samples Bach’s “Toccata and Fugue in D minor” (literally Dracula’s theme song) and makes for one of the strangest instrumentals I’ve ever heard. There are a lot of ideas and experiments that Carti wanted to try here, but they either majorly hit or miss the target. A majority of the album became quite forgettable for me. Particularly towards the middle and latter half of the album. I’d feel I’m either being beaten or bored to death with some of these beats. WLR does bring Carti back into that cloud rap, melodic vibe that he became popular for on songs like “Sky”, “Place”, “New N3on” and “Over”. All of which have this airy, psychedelic tone to them, and Carti manages to ride these beats like it's nothing. These tracks are quite honestly the highlight of the album and If WLR had sounded like these four songs for the whole album I would’ve been content. The experimentation with more abrasive sounds as I said before does work sometimes, but WLR’s insistence on this punk-trap aesthetic hinders it from what makes Carti’s music (to me at least) shine as it did on Die Lit. When it comes to lyrics, don’t expect Carti to drop some heavy bars, in case you weren’t aware that’s not his thing. Like most other rappers in the “mumble rap” genre, Carti focuses more so on melodies than bars, so expect a ton of repetition on hooks and verses. Carti does away with the “baby voice” that he became known for, he sounds more raspy and angry most of the time. The lyrics here seemingly match each song’s tone. On the heavier, abrasive tracks. Carti’s bold and questionably violent, as he tells listeners on the hook of “No Sl33p” (“when I go to sleep I dream ‘bout murder.”). Whereas on songs like “Sky”, Carti’s euphoric and drug-riddled (“I’m tryin’ to get high ‘till I can’t feel nothin’. I could fall out the sky and I still won’t feel nothin’.”). Then you have these truth bombs being dropped like Carti was trying to go deep but in execution, it’s just odd. Such as the second verse on “Punk Monk” where Carti reveals how he was trying to get Trippie Redd signed to a major label, problems with Pi’erre, etc. It’s like why? Carti spent up until this point in the album with this new punk vibe, he’s moshing and partying and now he suddenly wants to get insightful? Even the aforementioned “Control” is a strange attempt at a love song, where Carti says he’s not a stalker but spends the majority of the song creepily pleading with his girl or ex-girl like a stalker. There are guest features here as well, a matter of fact some of the best songs on WLR are the ones with guests. Kanye West comes through on the Yeezus-like “Go2DaMoon” where he spits one of his best lines in a long time. (“Everybody wear a costume, spray a little extra perfume YEEZYs in the stock room, that’s the name, make the stock boom.”). Kid Cudi chimes in on “M3tamorphosis”, both rappers are in a state of pure zen where they feel nobody can tell them anything, Cudi’s hums and the song’s booming bass match up perfectly. Future spins by on “Teen X”, where both he and Carti splurge on their drug habits of lean and ecstasy, with Carti bringing back the baby voice for old times sake. Overall, Whole Lotta Red is a mixed bag. It’s evident Carti wanted to experiment with his sound and take his music to another realm. When it works, it certainly does, but when it fumbles it fumbles badly. For every good song I mentioned, there’s an equally bad one. Supposedly there may be a deluxe version of Whole Lotta Red coming out at some point so that could maybe fix the album’s shortcomings? but that’s still up in the air. As a final rating, I’m giving Whole Lotta Red a 5/10. There are a handful of good songs here, most of which are great to vibe to and capture Playboi Carti’s spirit. However, there are a lot of questionable and weirdly produced tracks that are mediocre and forgettable, which really bog the whole album down. I do still think it’s worth a listen if you haven’t heard WLR yet, maybe there’s something there that you might like that I criticized, or you might feel the same way I did. Favourite Tracks: Rockstar Made, Go2DaMoon, Stop Breathing, M3tamorphosis, Teen X, New N3on, Over, Sky, Die4Guy.
